{{lowercase|title=fit-PC}} {{Infobox Information appliance |name = fit-PC2, fit-PC2i |connectivity = 802.11b/g Wi-Fi
1000baseT Ethernet (2x GbE in fit-PC2i)
6 x USB 2.0 ports (4 in fit-PC2i)
line-out, line-in, microphone
S/PDIF (and RS232 in fit-PC2i) |os = Linux Mint
Windows XP
Windows 7 |power = 6W @ 12 V DC |cpu = Intel Atom Z550 (2 GHz) / Z530 (1.6 GHz) / Z510 (1.1 GHz) |memory = 1 GB DDR2
Up to 2 GB |media = 2.5" 160 GB SATA hard disk
mini-SD slot |display = DVI 1920x1200 through HDMI connector |dimensions = 10.1 x 11.5 x 2.7 cm |image = }} {{Infobox Information appliance |name = fit-PC Slim |connectivity = 802.11b/g Wi-Fi
[[100baseT]] Ethernet
3 x [[Universal Serial Bus|USB 2.0]] ports
Headphones, microphone
[[RS232|Serial]] |os = [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]
[[Gentoo Linux]]
[[Windows XP]] |power = 6W @ 12 V DC |cpu = [[Geode (processor)|Geode]] LX 800 |memory = 512 MB [[DDR SDRAM]] |media = 2.5" 60 GB [[AT Attachment|IDE]] [[hard disk]] |display = [[VGA]] 1920x1440 |dimensions = 10 x 11 x 3 cm |image = }} {{Infobox Information appliance |name = fit-PC 1.0 |connectivity = 2 x [[100baseT]] Ethernet
2 x [[Universal Serial Bus|USB 2.0]] ports
Headphones, microphone
[[RS232|Serial]] |os = [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]
[[Gentoo Linux]]
[[Windows XP]] |power = 5W @ 5 V DC |cpu = [[Geode (processor)|Geode]] LX 800 |memory = 256 MB [[DDR SDRAM]] |media = 2.5" 40 GB (older versions) / 60 GB (newer versions) [[AT Attachment|IDE]] [[hard disk]] |display = [[VGA]] 1920x1440 |dimensions = 12 x 11.6 x 4 cm |image = [[Image:CompuLab Fit-pc1.0 front back.jpg|200px]] }} The '''fit-PC''' is a small, light, fan-less [[nettop]] computer manufactured by the [[Israel]]i company CompuLab. Many fit-PC models are available. fit-PC 1.0 was introduced in July 2007, fit-PC Slim was introduced in September 2008, fit-PC 2 was introduced in May 2009, fit-PC 3 was introduced in early 2012, and fit-PC 4 was introduced spring 2014. The [[Information appliance|device]] is power-efficient (fit-PC 1 was about 5 W) and therefore considered{{by whom|date=January 2011}} to be a [[green computing]] project, capable of using [[open source software]] and creating minimal [[electronic waste]].{{cite web | title = Tiniest Linux system, yet? | url = http://www.linuxdevices.com/news/NS2102697273.html | publisher = LinuxDevices.com | date = September 16, 2008 | accessdate = 2008-09-27 }}{{cite web | title = Tiny PC sips power, runs Linux | url = http://www.linuxdevices.com/news/NS5551137361.html | publisher = LinuxDevices.com | date = July 19, 2007 | accessdate = 2008-02-21 }}{{cite web | title = Fit PC—A Tiny Linux PC that Fits Anywhere | url = http://www.extremetech.com/article2/0,1697,2194862,00.asp | publisher = ExtremeTech | accessdate = 2008-02-21 }} ==Current models== ===fit-PC2=== On February 19, 2009, Compulab announced the fit-PC2, which is "a major upgrade to the fit-PC product line".{{cite web | title = New fit-PC model - fit-PC2 | url = http://www.fit-pc.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=778 | publisher = CompuLab | accessdate = 2009-02-19 }} Detailed specifications for the fit-PC2 include an Intel Atom Z5xx ''[[Silverthorne (microprocessor)|Silverthorne]]'' processor (1.1/1.6/2.0 GHz options), up to 2GB of [[Random-access memory|RAM]], 160GB SATA Hard Drive, GigaBit LAN and more. The fit-PC2 is also capable of HD video playback. Its declared power consumption is only 6W, and according to the manufacturer, it saves 96% of the power used by a standard desktop. fit-PC2 is the most power efficient PC on the [[Energy star|Energy-Star]] list. The fit-PC2 is based on the [[GMA 500]] (Graphics Media Accelerator). Unfortunately the open source driver included in Linux kernel 2.6.39 does not support VA-API video or OpenGL/3D acceleration.{{cite web | title = An Open-Source Intel GMA 500 Driver Appears | url = https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=OTE0NQ | publisher = Phoronix | accessdate = 2011-06-27 }} The fit-PC2 is being phased out and is being replaced by the fitlet, the fitlet was designed to replace the groundbreaking (and still popular) CompuLab fit-PC2.http://www.fit-pc.com/web/about/news/fitlet-announcement/ ===fit-PC2i=== On December 2, 2009, Compulab announced the fit-PC2i, a fit-PC2 variation targeting networking and industrial applications.{{cite web | title = fit-PC2i announced - fit-PC2 | url = http://www.fit-pc2.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=39&t=1156/ | publisher = CompuLab | accessdate = 2009-12-30 }} fit-PC2i adds a second Gbit Ethernet port, [[Wake-on-LAN]], [[S/PDIF]] output and RS232 port, has two fewer USB ports, and no IR. ===fit-PC3=== The fit-PC3 has been released early 2012. See the [[fit-PC3]] article. ===fit-PC4=== The fit-PC4 has been released spring 2014. ===fitlet=== The fitlet has been announced January 14, 2015.{{cite web | title = fitlet announced - fitlet | url = http://www.fit-pc.com/web/products/fitlet/ | publisher = CompuLab | accessdate = 2015-01-14 }} It has 3 CPU/[[System on a chip|SoC]] variations, and 5 feature variations, though only 7 models have been announced so far. ==Obsolete models== ===fit-PC Slim=== On September 16, 2008, Compulab announced the Fit-PC Slim, which at 11 x 10 x 3 cm is smaller than fit-PC 1.0. ====Hardware==== fit-PC Slim uses 500 MHz AMD [[Geode (processor)|Geode]] [[Geode (processor)#Geode LX|LX800]] processor and has 512mb soldered-on RAM. The computer includes a VGA output, a serial port with a custom connector, Ethernet, b/g WLAN, and 3 USB ports (2 on the front panel). The system has an upgradeable 2.5" 60GB ATA hard drive. ====Software==== fit-PC Slim has General Software BIOS supporting [[Preboot Execution Environment|PXE]] and booting from a USB CDROM or USB thumb drive. It is pre-installed with either Windows Vista or with [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] 8.10 and [[Gentoo Linux]] 2008.0 . Also Windows Embedded can be used, or pre-installed on a FlowDrive. ====Availability==== The fit-PC Slim end-of-life was announced on 19 June 2009 with the general availability of fit-PC2. ===fit-PC 1.0=== fit-PC 1.0 is an earlier model that has the following differences * Limited to 256mb RAM * No Wi-Fi * Dual 100BaseT Ethernet * Larger form factor - 12 x 11.6 x 4 cm * Only 2 USB ports * Hard disk is upgradeable * No power button and indicator LEDs * 5 V power supply ==See also== *[[Trim-Slice]], an [[ARM architecture|ARM]] mini-computer also made by CompuLab *[[Industrial PC]] *[[Media center (disambiguation)]] *[[Media PC]] *[[Nettop]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.fit-pc.com fit-PC website] * [http://www.compulab.co.il Compulab website] * [http://www.fit-pc.com.au fit-PC Australia website] * [http://www.fit-pc2.com/forum/ fit-PC2 Users forum] * [http://fitpc.com/ fit-PC US Website] {{Linux mini computers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fit-Pc}} [[Category:Computers and the environment]] [[Category:Israeli brands]] [[Category:Linux-based devices]] [[Category:Nettop]] [[Category:Products introduced in 2007]]

revision.comment: +Spring scale to "See also" section
revision.text:
A '''force meter''' is an instrument to measure the magnitude of a [[force]]. This is often just a spring contained within a cylinder that has a scale to mark the extension of the spring produced by the force. The unit of force is the [[Newton (unit)|Newton]] (symbol N) in the [[International System of Units]] and in that case the meter may be referred to as a '''newtonmeter'''.
A spring-based force meter with uniformly marked scale intervals is relying on [[Hooke's law]] which states that the extension (or compression) of the spring is proportional to the applied force.
==See also== *[[Dynamometer]] *[[Newton metre]], the units for torque *[[Spring scale]]
[[Category:Measuring instruments]]
{{physics-stub}}

'''GENWI''' is a privately held technology company based in San Jose, CA that provides a mobile content enablement platform.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/punes-persistent-systems-acquires-san-jose-based-genwi/articleshow/51648458.cms|title=Pune's Persistent Systems acquires San Jose-based Genwi|last=Sangani|first=Priyanka|date=2016-04-01|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>{{Orphan|date=December 2010}}
GENWI was a free [[Web application|web-based]] news reader, or [[feed aggregator|aggregator]], initially released in March 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.masternewmedia.org/news/2007/03/20/social_media_networking_meets_rss.htm |title=Social Media Networking Meets RSS Content Aggregation And Promotion: Genwi |date=2007-03-20 |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref> Genwi provided a news feed service by enabling users to publish their feeds to one profile and follow others' news feeds in the [[feed reader]] – this feed reader was called "Wire" and was capable of reading [[RSS]], [[Media RSS]], iTunes RSS and [[ATOM]] feeds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://webtrends.about.com/od/webfeedsyndicationrss/tp/Top-Online-RSS-Readers.htm |publisher=About.com |title=Top Online RSS Readers |author=Nations, Daniel |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref> Genwi offered a suite of [[social networking]] features built into the RSS reader. Users were able to add friends, send messages, leave comments and share individual feed items. The site underwent a major redesign in November 2008<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/11/20/genwi-further-blurs-the-line-between-a-feed-reader-and-a-friend-reader/ |publisher=TechCrunch |date=November 20, 2008 |author=Schonfeld, Erick |title=Genwi Further Blurs the Line Between a Feed Reader and a Friend Reader |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref> and was shut down in 2009.
In January 2010, '''GENWI, Inc.''' used the same technology that built their RSS reader to launch iSites.us,<ref>{{cite web |last=Parr |first=Ben |url=http://mashable.com/2010/01/20/isites/ |title=Create Your Own iPhone or Android App in Minutes With iSites |publisher=Mashable |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref> a smartphone app builder and management system, which enables businesses to build applications for iPhone and Android using RSS, ATOM or social feeds.<ref>{{cite web |title=iSites Features |url=http://iSites.us |work=Features |accessdate=5 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501034802/http://isites.us/ |archivedate=1 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> GENWI uses cloud-based technology to keep more than 1,500 native apps up-to-date and to instantly build HTML5 apps for iPhone.<ref>{{cite web |last=Anthony |first=Sebastian |url=http://downloadsquad.switched.com/2011/03/30/isites-overhauled-now-lets-you-publish-cloud-based-html5-iphone/ |title=iSites overhauled, now lets you publish cloud-based HTML5 iPhone apps in minutes |publisher=AOL Switched Download Squad |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref>
In September 2011, GENWI launched Conde Nast's "The Daily W" app and rebranded the iSites brand back to GENWI and now helps publishers and brands create engaging native and HTML5 apps with a cloud-based mobile content management system, or mCMS.
GENWI is short for "Generation Wireless" and is headquartered in San Jose, California.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foursquare.com/venue/3460717|title=GENWI|work=Foursquare|accessdate=5 May 2011}}</ref>
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.genwi.com GENWI]
[[Category:Mobile technology]] [[Category:Social information processing]] [[Category:Smartphones]]

revision.comment: refine categories
revision.text:
'''GreenSun Energy''' is a [[Jerusalem]]-based Israeli company that has developed a new process for producing [[electricity]] from [[solar energy]]. As [[The Economist]] points out, solar energy is a logical development since "Israel is a country with plenty of sunshine, lots of sand and quite a few clever physicists and chemists."<ref name=r1> Solar energy in Israel; It's a knockout, Jul 23rd 2009, [[The Economist]] print edition [http://www.economist.com/sciencetechnology/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14082027]</ref>
==Process== Traditional [[photovoltaic cells]] are made from thin sheets of [[silicon]] covered by glass plates. In the GreenSun process, it is only the outer edges of the [[glass]] plates that are covered by thin strips of silicon. The physicists and chemists at GreenSun, led by [[Renata Reisfeld]], coat the glass with metallic [[nanoparticle]]s and [[dye]]s to cause the sunlight falling on the glass to diffuse sideways toward the edges where the silicon strips turn it into electricity. <ref name=r1/>
A mixture of dyes is used to capture and absorb a wide spectrum of available light. Having absorbed the sunlight, the fluorescent dyes then re-radiate it. Interaction with the metallic nanoparticles turns light into a form of [[electromagnetic radiation]] known as [[surface plasmon]]s. The surface plasmons propagate over the glass surface and are intercepted by the silicon strips at the edges. The company would not reveal which metals are used in the process.<ref name=r1/>
Because the process uses less silicon, it is far less expensive than conventional [[photovoltaic module]]s. It is also more efficient. In a conventional photovoltaic cell, much of the sun's energy is lost as heat because the energy of light varies across the spectrum (red light is less energetic than blue, for example). Only a particular amount of energy is needed to knock an [[electron]] free from the silicon [[atom]]s. If the sunlight is more energetic than necessary, more energy than usual is lost as heat. Sunlight scatters its energy, but the dye/nanoparticle mix in the GreenSun process delivers plasmons and [[photons]] of the right energy to knock electrons free more efficiently.<ref name=r1/>
==Economics== GreenEnergy CEO [[Amnon Leikovich]] claims that the process, once put into production, could deliver electricity at about double the cost of a conventional power station.{{Clarify|date=August 2009}}<!-- this says the process is much less efficient than conventional one --> Traditional photovoltaic modules deliver electricity at about five times the cost of a conventional power plant. Leikovich hopes that costs can be brought down even further.<ref name=r1/>
According to corporate spokesmen Eitan Shmueli, GreenSun's photovoltaic panels are capable of producing electricity from low-intensity sunlight on cloudy days and from sunlight that reaches them from any angle. The company claims that can turn the windows or walls of buildings into electricity-generating photovoltaic panels.<ref>New tech could coat buildings in efficient solar-energy panels, Avi Bar-Eli, HaAretz, July 30, 2009 [http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1104003.html]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.greensun.biz/ Green Sun Energy company website] *Audio interview with Renata Reisfeld, CTO and Chief Scientist [http://audiovideo.economist.com/?fr_story=7f8b0d5b6ee20f7f5ab080e25d0372559c43bb37&rf=bm]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Greensun Energy}} [[Category:Photovoltaics manufacturers]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of Israel]] [[Category:Solar energy in Israel]] [[Category:Renewable energy technology companies]] [[Category:Companies based in Jerusalem]]

revision.text:
'''HASQI''', ''Hearing-Aid Speech Quality Index'', is a measure of audio quality originally designed for the evaluation of speech quality for those with a [[hearing aid]],.<ref name="kates2010">{{cite journal|last1=Kates|first1=James|last2=Arehart|first2=Kathryn|title=The hearing-aid speech quality index (HASQI)|journal=Journal of the Audio Engineering Society|date=2010|volume=58|issue=5|pages=363–381}}</ref><ref name="kates2014">{{cite journal|last1=Kates|first1=James|last2=Arehart|first2=Kathryn|title=The hearing-aid speech quality index (HASQI) version 2|journal=Journal of the Audio Engineering Society|date=2014|volume=62|issue=3|pages=99–117}}</ref> It has also been shown to be able to gauge audio quality for non-speech sounds and for listeners without a [[hearing loss]].<ref name="kressner">{{cite journal|doi=10.1109/TASL.2012.2217132|title=Evaluating the Generalization of the Hearing Aid Speech Quality Index (HASQI)|journal=IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech, and Language Processing|volume=21|issue=2|pages=407|year=2013|last1=Kressner|first1=Abigail A.|last2=Anderson|first2=David V.|last3=Rozell|first3=Christopher J.}}</ref>
== Background == While the perception of audio quality can be gauged through perceptual measurements, the testing is time-consuming to undertake. Consequently, a number of metrics have been developed to allow audio quality to be evaluated without the need for human listening. Standardized examples from [[telephony]] include [[PESQ]], [[POLQA]], [[PEVQ]] and [[PEAQ]]. HASQI was originally developed by Kates and Arehart to evaluate how the distortions introduced by [[hearing aids]] degrade quality.<ref name="kates2010" /> They also produced a new version in 2014.<ref name="kates2014" />
Kressner et al.<ref name="kressner" /> tested a speech corpus different from the dataset used to develop HASQI and showed that the index generalizes well for listeners without a hearing loss with a performance comparable to [[PESQ]]. Kendrick et al.<ref name="kendrick2015">{{cite journal|last1=Kendrick|first1=Paul|last2=Li|first2=Francis|last3=Fazenda|first3=Bruno|last4=Jackson|first4=Iain|last5=Cox|first5=Trevor|title=Perceived Audio Quality of Sounds Degraded by Nonlinear Distortions and Single-Ended Assessment Using HASQI|journal=Journal of the Audio Engineering Society|date=2015|volume=63|issue=9|pages=698–712|url=http://www.aes.org/e-lib/browse.cfm?elib=17873}}</ref> showed that HASQI can grade the audio quality of music and geophonic, biophonic, and anthrophonic quotidian sounds, although their study used a more limited set of degradations.
== Method == HASQI and its 2014 revision are double-ended methods requiring both a clean reference and the degraded signal to allow evaluation. The index attempts to capture the effects of noise, nonlinear distortion, linear filtering and spectral changes, by computing the difference or correlation between key audio features. This is done by examining short-time signal envelopes to quantify the degradation caused by noise and nonlinear filtering, and long-time signal envelopes to quantify the effects of linear filtering. Version 2 of HASQI includes a model to capture some aspects of the peripheral [[auditory system]] for both normal and hearing impaired listeners.
Kendrick et al. developed a blind (single-ended) method, bHASQI, using machine learning. This enables the audio quality to be evaluated from just the degraded signal without needing the clean reference.<ref name="kendrick2015" />
== See also == * Perceptual Evaluation of Speech Quality ([[PESQ]]) * Perceptual Objective Listening Quality Assessment ([[POLQA]]) * Perceptual Evaluation of Video Quality ([[PEVQ]]) * Perceptual Evaluation of Audio Quality ([[PEAQ]])
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Code for evaluating bHASQI [http://usir.salford.ac.uk/35954/ Source code for blind detection and metering of distortion and clipping]

{{Infobox drug | drug_name = | INN = | type =<!-- empty --> | IUPAC_name = | image = Hand Sanitizer.JPG | alt = | caption = A typical bottle of hand sanitizer gel <!-- Clinical data --> | synonyms = Hand sanitiser, hand antiseptic,<ref name=US2009>{{cite journal| title =Tentative Final Monograph for Health-Care Antiseptic Drug Products; Proposed Rule| volume =74| issue =56| publisher =United States Federal Food and Drug Administration| date =March 2009| url =http://www.fda.gov/OHRMS/DOCKETS/ac/05/briefing/2005-4184B1_01_16-FDA-TAB15.pdf| pages =12613–12617| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100310201814/http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/05/briefing/2005-4184B1_01_16-FDA-TAB15.pdf| archivedate =2010-03-10| df =}}</ref> hand disinfectant | pronounce = | tradename = | Drugs.com = | MedlinePlus = | pregnancy_AU = <!-- A/B1/B2/B3/C/D/X --> | pregnancy_AU_comment = | pregnancy_US = <!-- A/B/C/D/X/N --> | pregnancy_category= | routes_of_administration = | legal_AU = <!-- S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9 or Unscheduled--> | legal_AU_comment = | legal_CA = <!-- OTC, Rx-only, Schedule I, II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII --> | legal_DE = <!-- Anlage I, II, III --> | legal_NZ = <!-- Class A, B, C --> | legal_UK = <!-- GSL, P, POM, CD, CD Lic, CD POM, CD No Reg POM, CD (Benz) POM, CD (Anab) POM or CD Inv POM / Class A, B, C --> | legal_US = <!-- OTC/Rx-only/Schedule I, II, III, IV, V --> | legal_UN = <!-- N I, II, III, IV / P I, II, III, IV--> | legal_status = <!-- Free text --> <!-- Pharmacokinetic data --> | bioavailability = | protein_bound = | metabolism = | metabolites = | onset = | elimination_half-life = | duration_of_action = | excretion = <!-- Identifiers --> | CAS_number = | class = | ATCvet = | ATC_prefix = <!-- 'none' if uncategorised --> | ATC_suffix = | PubChem = | DrugBank = <!-- Chemical and physical data --> | chemical_formula = | molecular_weight = }} <!-- Definition and uses --> '''Hand sanitizer''' is a [[liquid]] generally used to decrease [[infectious agents]] on the [[hand]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=hand sanitizer - definition of hand sanitizer in English {{!}} Oxford Dictionaries|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/hand_sanitizer|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|accessdate=12 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918190157/https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/hand_sanitizer|archivedate=18 September 2017|df=}}</ref> Formulations of the [[alcohol]]-based type are preferable to [[hand washing]] with soap and water in most situations in the healthcare setting.<ref name=Bol2016>{{cite journal|last1=Bolon|first1=MK|title=Hand Hygiene: An Update.|journal=Infectious Disease Clinics of North America|date=September 2016|volume=30|issue=3|pages=591–607|pmid=27515139|doi=10.1016/j.idc.2016.04.007}}</ref> It is generally more effective at killing [[microorganisms]] and better tolerated than soap and water.<ref name=Boy2002/> Hand washing should still be carried out if contamination can be seen or following the use of the toilet.<ref name=WHO2015Use>{{cite book|title=The selection and use of essential medicines: Twentieth report of the WHO Expert Committee 2015 (including 19th WHO Model List of Essential Medicines and 5th WHO Model List of Essential Medicines for Children).|date=2015|publisher=WHO|isbn=9789240694941|pages=323|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/189763/1/9789241209946_eng.pdf?ua=1|accessdate=8 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220085929/http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/189763/1/9789241209946_eng.pdf?ua=1|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}}</ref> The general use of non-alcohol based versions has no recommendations.<ref name=Bol2016/> Outside the health care setting evidence to support the use of hand sanitizer over hand washing is poor.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=de Witt Huberts|first1=J|last2=Greenland|first2=K|last3=Schmidt|first3=WP|last4=Curtis|first4=V|title=Exploring the potential of antimicrobial hand hygiene products in reducing the infectious burden in low-income countries: An integrative review.|journal=American Journal of Infection Control|date=1 July 2016|volume=44|issue=7|pages=764–71|pmid=27061254|doi=10.1016/j.ajic.2016.01.045}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Meadows|first1=E|last2=Le Saux|first2=N|title=A systematic review of the effectiveness of antimicrobial rinse-free hand sanitizers for prevention of illness-related absenteeism in elementary school children.|journal=BMC Public Health|date=1 November 2004|volume=4|pages=50|pmid=15518593|doi=10.1186/1471-2458-4-50|pmc=534108}}</ref> They are available as liquids, gels, and foams.<ref name=Boy2002/>
<!-- Formulation --> Alcohol-based versions typically contain some combination of [[isopropyl alcohol]], [[ethanol]] (ethyl alcohol), or [[Propan-1-ol|''n''-propanol]].<ref name=Boy2002/> Versions that contain 60 to 95% alcohol are most effective.<ref name=Boy2002/> Care should be taken as they are [[flammable]].<ref name=Bol2016/> Alcohol-based hand sanitizer works against a variety of [[microorganisms]] but not [[spores]].<ref name=Boy2002>{{cite journal|last1=Boyce|first1=JM|last2=Pittet|first2=D|last3=Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory|first3=Committee.|last4=HICPAC/SHEA/APIC/IDSA Hand Hygiene Task|first4=Force.|title=Guideline for Hand Hygiene in Health-Care Settings. Recommendations of the Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee and the HICPAC/SHEA/APIC/IDSA Hand Hygiene Task Force. Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America/Association for Professionals in Infection Control/Infectious Diseases Society of America.|journal=MMWR. Recommendations and Reports : Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. Recommendations and Reports|date=25 October 2002|volume=51|issue=RR-16|pages=1–45, quiz CE1–4|pmid=12418624}}</ref> Some versions contain compounds such as [[glycerol]] to prevent drying of the skin.<ref name=Boy2002/> Non-alcohol based versions may contain [[benzalkonium chloride]] or [[triclosan]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Long|first1=Bruce W.|last2=Rollins|first2=Jeannean Hall|last3=Smith|first3=Barbara J.|title=Merrill's Atlas of Radiographic Positioning and Procedures|date=2015|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780323319652|page=16|edition=13|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ow8mBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA16|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918190157/https://books.google.com/books?id=ow8mBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA16|archivedate=2017-09-18|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Baki|first1=Gabriella|last2=Alexander|first2=Kenneth S.|title=Introduction to Cosmetic Formulation and Technology|date=2015|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118763780|page=173|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tM_0BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA173|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918190158/https://books.google.com/books?id=tM_0BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA173|archivedate=2017-09-18|df=}}</ref>
<!-- History and culture --> Alcohol has been used as an [[antiseptic]] at least as early as 1363 with evidence to support its use becoming available in the late 1800s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Block|first1=Seymour Stanton|title=Disinfection, Sterilization, and Preservation|journal=Soil Science|volume=124|issue=6|date=2001|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9780683307405|page=14|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3f-kPJ17_TYC&pg=PA14|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918190157/https://books.google.com/books?id=3f-kPJ17_TYC&pg=PA14|archivedate=2017-09-18|df=|bibcode=1977SoilS.124..378B|doi=10.1097/00010694-197712000-00013}}</ref> Alcohol-based hand sanitizer has been commonly used in Europe since at least the 1980s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Miller|first1=Chris H.|last2=Palenik|first2=Charles John|title=Infection Control and Management of Hazardous Materials for the Dental Team|date=2016|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780323476577|page=269|edition=5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oySKCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA269|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918190157/https://books.google.com/books?id=oySKCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA269|archivedate=2017-09-18|df=}}</ref> The alcohol-based version is on the [[World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines]], the most effective and safe medicines needed in a [[health system]].<ref name=WHO19th>{{cite web|title=WHO Model List of Essential Medicines (19th List)|url=http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/EML_2015_FINAL_amended_NOV2015.pdf?ua=1|work=World Health Organization|accessdate=8 December 2016|date=April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213052708/http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/EML_2015_FINAL_amended_NOV2015.pdf?ua=1|archivedate=13 December 2016|df=}}</ref> The wholesale cost in the [[developing world]] is about US$1.40–3.70 per liter bottle.<ref name=ERC2014>{{cite web|title=Alcohol, isopropyl|url=http://mshpriceguide.org/en/single-drug-information/?DMFId=15&searchYear=2014|website=International Drug Price Indicator Guide|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=WHO2015Use/>
==Uses==
===General public=== The Clean Hands campaign by the US [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) instructs the public hand washing. Alcohol-based hand sanitizer is recommended only if soap and water are not available.<ref name=CDC2017Pub/>
:''When using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer:'' :*''Apply product to the palm of one hand.'' :*''Rub hands together.'' :*''Rub the product over all surfaces of hands and fingers until hands are dry.''<ref name=CDC2017Pub>{{cite web | url = https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/when-how-handwashing.html | title = Clean Hands Save Lives! | publisher = Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | date = December 11, 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170818165220/https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/when-how-handwashing.html | archivedate = August 18, 2017 | df = }}</ref>
The evidence for hand hygiene in school generally is of poor quality.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Willmott|first1=M|last2=Nicholson|first2=A|last3=Busse|first3=H|last4=MacArthur|first4=GJ|last5=Brookes|first5=S|last6=Campbell|first6=R|title=Effectiveness of hand hygiene interventions in reducing illness absence among children in educational settings: a systematic review and meta-analysis.|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|date=January 2016|volume=101|issue=1|pages=42–50|pmid=26471110|doi=10.1136/archdischild-2015-308875|pmc=4717429}}</ref>
===Health care=== [[File:Handsprit.jpg|thumb|right|Hand alcohol in a hospital]] Alcohol-based hand sanitizer is more convenient compared to [[hand washing]] with soap and water in most situations in the healthcare setting.<ref name=Bol2016/> It is generally more effective at killing [[microorganisms]] and better tolerated than soap and water.<ref name=Boy2002/> Hand washing should still be carried out if contamination can be seen or following the use of the [[toilet]].<ref name=WHO2015Use/>
Hand sanitizer that contains at least 60 percent alcohol or contains a "persistent antiseptic" should be used.<ref name="CDC">[https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/ CDC – Handwashing: Clean Hands Save Lives] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729161705/https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/ |date=2017-07-29 }}</ref><ref> {{cite journal | title =Dirty Hands Spread Dangerous Diseases like H1N1 (aka swine flu) | journal =San Jose Mercury News | date =25 April 2009 }} </ref> Alcohol rubs kill many different kinds of bacteria, including [[antibiotic resistant]] bacteria and [[Tuberculosis|TB]] bacteria. 90% alcohol rubs are highly flammable, but kill many kinds of viruses, including [[enveloped virus]]es such as the [[flu virus]], the common [[cold virus]], and [[HIV]], though is notably ineffective against the [[rabies virus]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 18519460 | doi=10.1542/peds.2007-2597 | volume=121 | issue=6 | title=Reducing absenteeism from gastrointestinal and respiratory illness in elementary school students: a randomized, controlled trial of an infection-control intervention | date=June 2008 | author=Sandora TJ, Shih MC, Goldmann DA | journal=Pediatrics | pages=e1555–62}} </ref><ref>[http://www.jointcommission.org/NR/rdonlyres/F76BC658-5554-4A82-89ED-67E36F033CF8/0/Infection_Control_Brochure.pdf Infection Control Campaign brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090102180425/http://www.jointcommission.org/NR/rdonlyres/F76BC658-5554-4A82-89ED-67E36F033CF8/0/Infection_Control_Brochure.pdf |date=January 2, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.4065/79.1.109| pmid = 14708954| title = Hand Hygiene: A Frequently Missed Lifesaving Opportunity During Patient Care| journal = Mayo Clinic Proceedings| volume = 79| issue = 1| pages = 109–16| year = 2004| last1 = Trampuz| first1 = Andrej| last2 = Widmer| first2 = Andreas F}}</ref>
90% alcohol rubs are more effective against [[viruses]] than most other form of hand washing.<ref name=cvvs/> Isopropyl alcohol will kill 99.99 percent or more of all non-spore forming bacteria in less than 30 seconds, both in the laboratory and on human skin.<ref name="CDC"/><ref name="Hibbard 194–207">{{cite journal | last =Hibbard| first =John S. | title =Analyses Comparing the Antimicrobial Activity and Safety of Current Antiseptic Agents | journal =J. Infusion Nursing | volume =28 | issue =3 | pages =194–207 | date =May–June 2005 | doi =10.1097/00129804-200505000-00008 | pmid=15912075}}</ref>
The alcohol in hand sanitizers may not have the 10–15 seconds exposure time required to denature proteins and [[lysis|lyse]] cells in too low quantities (0.3 mL) or concentrations (below 60%).<ref name="Boyce John M., Pittet Didier">{{cite journal | author1 =Boyce John M. | author2 =Pittet Didier | title =Guideline for Hand Hygiene in Health-Care Settings, Recommendations of the Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee and the HICPAC/SHEA/APIC/IDSA Hand Hygiene Task Force | journal =Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | date =October 25, 2002 | url =https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5116a1.htm | volume =51 | pages =1–44 | accessdate =2010-02-18 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100215205218/http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5116a1.htm | archivedate =February 15, 2010 | df = }}</ref> In environments with high lipids or protein waste (such as food processing), the use of alcohol hand rubs alone may not be sufficient to ensure proper hand hygiene.<ref name="Boyce John M., Pittet Didier"/>
For health care settings like hospitals and clinics, optimum alcohol concentration to kill bacteria is 70% to 95%.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kramer |first1=Axel |last2=Rudolph |first2=Peter |last3=Kampf |first3=Gonter |last4=Pittet |first4=Didier |date=27 April 2002 |title=Limited efficacy of alcohol-based hand gels |journal=Lancet |volume=359 |issue=9316 |pages=1489–1490 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(02)08426-X |pmid=11988252}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Pietsch |first=Hanns |date=2001 |title=Hand Antiseptics: Rubs Versus Scrubs, Alcoholic Solutions Versus Alcoholic Gels |journal=J. Hospital Infection |volume=48 |issue=Supl A |pages=S33–S36 |doi=10.1016/S0195-6701(01)90010-6}}</ref> Products with alcohol concentrations as low as 40% are available in American stores, according to researchers at [[East Tennessee State University]].<ref> {{cite journal |last=Reynolds |first=Scott A. |author2=Foster Levy |author3=Elaine S. Walker |title=Hand Sanitizer Alert |journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases |volume=12 |issue=3 |date=March 2006 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol12no03/05-0955.htm |accessdate=2007-02-02 |doi=10.3201/eid1203.050955 |pages=527–9 |pmid=16710985 |pmc=3291447 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202214446/http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol12no03/05-0955.htm |archivedate=2007-02-02 |df= }}</ref>
Alcohol rub sanitizers kill most bacteria, and fungi, and stop some viruses. Alcohol rub sanitizers containing at least 70% alcohol (mainly [[ethyl alcohol]]) kill 99.9% of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application and 99.99% to 99.999%<ref group="note">research papers often use "n-log" to mean a reduction of n on a (base 10) logarithmic scale graphing the number of bacteria, thus "5-log" means a reduction by a factor of 10<sup>5</sup>, or 99.999%</ref> in one minute.<ref name=cvvs>{{ cite journal | last = Rotter M.| title = Hand washing and hand disinfection | journal = Hospital Epidemiology and Infection Control| volume = 87 | year = 1999 }}</ref>
For health care, optimal disinfection requires attention to all exposed surfaces such as around the fingernails, between the fingers, on the back of the thumb, and around the wrist. Hand alcohol should be thoroughly rubbed into the hands and on the lower [[forearm]] for a duration of at least 30 seconds and then allowed to air dry.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Girou | first =Emmanuelle | author2 =Sabrina Layou | author3 =Patrick Legrand | author4 =Francoise Oppein | author5 =Christian Brun-Buisson | title =Efficacy of handrubbing with alcohol based solution versus standard handwashing with antiseptic soap: randomised clinical trial | journal =British Medical Journal | volume =325 | issue =362 | date =August 2002 | url =http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/325/7360/362 | accessdate =2009-10-16 | pmid =12183307 | doi =10.1136/bmj.325.7360.362 | page =362 | pmc =117885 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20091127104620/http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/325/7360/362 | archivedate =2009-11-27 | df = }}</ref>
Use of alcohol-based hand gels dries skin less, leaving more moisture in the [[Epidermis (skin)|epidermis]], than hand washing with antiseptic/antimicrobial [[soap]] and [[water]].<ref name=Ped01>{{cite journal | url = http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/16307649/Less_skin_irritation_from_alcohol-based_disinfectant_than_from_detergent_used_for_hand_disinfection | title = Less skin irritation from alcohol-based disinfectant than from detergent used for hand disinfection | journal = British Journal of Dermatology | year = 2005 | volume = 153 | issue = 6 | pages = 1142–1146 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2133.2005.06875.x | pmid = 16307649 | author = Pedersen, L.K., E. Held, J.D. Johansen, T. Agner | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160306193444/http://biomedexperts.com/abstract.bme/16307649/less_skin_irritation_from_alcohol-based_disinfectant_than_from_detergent_used_for_hand_disinfection | archivedate = 2016-03-06 | df = }}</ref><ref> {{cite journal | title = Short-term effects of alcohol-based disinfectant and detergent on skin irritation| author =Pedersen, Kynemund, Elisabeth Held, Jeanne Duus Johansen, Tove Agner|journal=Contact Dermatitis| year=2005|volume=52| pmid=15725285| doi=10.1111/j.0105-1873.2005.00504.x | issue = 2 | pages = 82–7}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal | last =Boyce | first =John M. | title =Using Alcohol for Hand Antisepsis: Dispelling Old Myths | journal =Infection Control and Hospital Epidemiology | volume =21| issue =7 |date=July 2000 | pmid =10926392 | doi =10.1086/501784 | pages =438–41 }}</ref><ref name="Boyce 2000 442">{{cite journal | last =Boyce | first =John M. |author2=Kelliher, Susan |author3=Vallande, Nancy | title =Skin Irritation and Dryness Associated With Two Hand-Hygiene Regimens: Soap-and-Water Hand Washing Versus Hand Antisepsis With an Alcoholic Hand Gel | journal =Infection Control and Hospital Epidemiology | volume =21| issue =7 |date=July 2000 | pmid =10926393 | doi =10.1086/501785 | pages =442–8 }}</ref>
===Not indicated=== There are certain situations during which [[hand washing]] with water and soap are preferred over hand sanitizer, these include: eliminating bacterial spores of ''[[Clostridioides difficile (bacteria)|Clostridioides difficile]]'', parasites such as ''[[Cryptosporidium]]'', and certain viruses like [[norovirus]] depending on the concentration of alcohol in the sanitizer (95% alcohol was seen to be most effective in eliminating most viruses).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gold |first1=Nina A. |last2=Avva |first2=Usha |title=Alcohol Sanitizer |journal=StatPearls |date=2018 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513254/ }}</ref> In addition, if hands are contaminated with fluids or other visible contaminates, hand washing is preferred as well as when after using the toilet and if discomfort develops from the residue of alcohol sanitizer use. <ref>{{cite journal |last1=Seal |first1=Kelsey |last2=Cimon |first2=Karen |last3=Argáez |first3=Charlene |title=Summary of Evidence |journal=PubMed Health |date=9 March 2017 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0097316/ |language=en}}</ref> Furthermore, CDC recommends hand sanitizers are not effective in removing chemicals such as pesticides.<ref name=CDC2018Hand>{{cite journal |title=When & How to Wash Your Hands {{!}} Handwashing {{!}} CDC |website=www.cdc.gov |url=https://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/when-how-handwashing.html |language=en-us|date=2018-10-04 }}</ref>
==Safety== ===Fire=== Alcohol gel can catch fire, producing a translucent blue flame. This is due to the [[flammable]] alcohol in the gel. Some hand sanitizer gels may not produce this effect due to a high concentration of water or moisturizing agents. There have been some rare instances where alcohol has been implicated in starting fires in the operating room, including a case where alcohol used as an antiseptic pooled under the surgical drapes in an operating room and caused a fire when a cautery instrument was used. Alcohol gel was not implicated. To minimize the risk of fire, alcohol rub users are instructed to rub their hands until dry, which indicates that the flammable alcohol has evaporated.<ref name=CDC_20030915>{{cite web| url = https://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/firesafety/default.htm| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403230557/http://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/firesafety/default.htm| archivedate=2007-04-03| title = Alcohol-Based Hand-Rubs and Fire Safety |date=September 15, 2003| accessdate = 2007-04-26| publisher = Centers for Disease Control and Prevention}}</ref> Fire departments suggest refills for the alcohol-based hand sanitizers can be stored with cleaning supplies away from heat sources or open flames.<ref>Ohio OAC 1301:7-7-3405.5</ref>{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}
===Skin=== Research shows that alcohol hand sanitizers do not pose any risk by eliminating beneficial microorganisms that are naturally present on the skin. The body quickly replenishes the beneficial microbes on the hands, often moving them in from just up the arms where there are fewer harmful microorganisms.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Aiello | title =Consumer antibacterial soaps: effective or just risky? | journal =Clin Infect Dis | year =2007 | doi =10.1086/519255 | first1 =A. E. | last2 =Larson | first2 =E. L. | last3 =Levy | first3 =S. B. | volume =45 | pages =S137–47 | pmid =17683018 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> However, alcohol may strip the skin of the outer layer of oil, which may have negative effects on barrier function of the skin. A study also shows that disinfecting hands with an antimicrobial detergent results in a greater barrier disruption of skin compared to alcohol solutions, suggesting an increased loss of skin lipids.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Löffler | first =Harald |author2=Günter Kampf | title = Hand disinfection: How irritant are alcohols? | journal = Journal of Hospital Infection | year = 2008 | volume = 70 | doi =10.1016/S0195-6701(08)60010-9 | pages =44–8 | pmid =18994681 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Pedersen|first=L.K.|year=2005|title=Less skin irritation from alcohol-based disinfectant than from detergent used for hand disinfection|journal=British Journal of Dermatology|volume=153|issue=6|pages=1142–1146|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2133.2005.06875.x|pmid=16307649|author2=E. Held|author3=J.D. Johansen|author4=T. Agner}}<!--| accessdate =2009-10-16--></ref>
===Ingestion=== In the United States, the [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) controls antimicrobial handsoaps and sanitizers as [[over-the-counter drug]]s (OTC) because they are intended for topical anti-microbial use to prevent disease in humans.<ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.issa.com/data/files/articles/88/generalchemical.pdf| title =GENERAL GUIDE TO CHEMICAL CLEANING PRODUCT REGULATION| publisher =International Sanitary Supply Association, Inc.| last =Daniel S. Wagner, Manager of Regulatory Compliance, ISSA| year =2000| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20091231233542/http://issa.com/data/files/articles/88/generalchemical.pdf| archivedate =2009-12-31| df =}}</ref> The FDA requires strict labeling which informs consumers on proper use of this OTC drug and dangers to avoid, including warning adults not to ingest, not to use in the eyes, to keep out of the reach of children, and to allow use by children only under adult supervision.<ref>{{cite journal| title =Decoding the Cosmetic Label| author =Judith E. Foulke| journal =FDA Consumer Magazine|date=May 1994}}</ref> According to the [[American Association of Poison Control Centers]], there were nearly 12,000 cases of hand sanitizer ingestion in 2006.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.cnn.com/HEALTH/blogs/paging.dr.gupta/2007/06/hand-sanitizer-on-rocks-please.html| title = Paging Dr. Gupta, Hand sanitizer risks| date = June 21, 2007| publisher = CNN| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090425180532/http://www.cnn.com/HEALTH/blogs/paging.dr.gupta/2007/06/hand-sanitizer-on-rocks-please.html| archivedate = April 25, 2009| df = }}</ref> If ingested, alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause alcohol poisoning in small children.<ref name=NBC>{{cite web | accessdate = 2007-07-15| url =http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/health/news-article.aspx?storyid=84913| title =Hand Sanitizers Could Be A Dangerous Poison To Unsupervised Children| publisher = NBC News Channel}}</ref> However, the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control]] recommends using hand sanitizer with children to promote good hygiene, under supervision, and furthermore recommends parents pack hand sanitizer for their children when traveling, to avoid their contracting disease from dirty hands.<ref>{{cite journal| journal =Travelers' Health – Yellow Book| volume =8| title=International Travel with Infants and Young Children|date=March 2009}}</ref>
There have been reported incidents of people [[Surrogate alcohol|drinking the gel]] in prisons and hospitals, where alcohol is not allowed, to become intoxicated leading to its withdrawal from some establishments.<ref>{{cite news| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/dorset/8272799.stm| title =Prisoner 'drunk on swine flu gel'| publisher =BBC news online| date=2009-09-24}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/24/well/live/dont-drink-the-hand-sanitizer.html Don’t Drink the Hand Sanitizer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170514020528/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/24/well/live/dont-drink-the-hand-sanitizer.html |date=2017-05-14 }} NY Times Retrieved March 2017</ref>
===Non-alcohol based=== On April 30, 2015, the FDA announced that they were requesting more scientific data based on the safety of hand sanitizer. Emerging science also suggests that for at least some health care antiseptic active ingredients, systemic exposure (full body exposure as shown by detection of antiseptic ingredients in the blood or urine) is higher than previously thought, and existing data raise potential concerns about the effects of repeated daily human exposure to some antiseptic active ingredients. This would include hand antiseptic products containing alcohol and [[triclosan]].<ref>{{cite news| url =http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm445002.htm| title =FDA issues proposed rule to address data gaps for certain active ingredients in health care antiseptics| publisher =U.S. Food and Drug Administration| date =2015-04-30| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150702001329/http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm445002.htm| archivedate =2015-07-02| df =}} </ref>
==Chemistry== Consumer alcohol-based hand sanitizers, and [[health care]] ''hand alcohol'' or ''alcohol hand antiseptic agents'', are [[antiseptic]] products used to avoid transmission of [[pathogen]]s. These exist in liquid, foam, and easy-flowing gel formulations. The level of [[alcohol]] varies between 60% and 95%.
== Types == Alcohol-based hand rubs are extensively used in the hospital environment as an alternative to antiseptic soaps. Hand-rubs in the hospital environment have two applications: hygienic hand rubbing and surgical hand disinfection. Alcohol based hand rubs provide a better skin tolerance as compared to antiseptic soap.<ref name="Boyce 2000 442"/> Hand rubs also prove to have more effective microbiological properties as compared to antiseptic soaps.
The same ingredients used in over-the-counter hand-rubs are also used in hospital hand-rubs: alcohols such [[ethanol]] and [[isopropanol]], sometimes combined with [[quats]] (quaternary ammonium cations) such as [[benzalkonium chloride]]. Quats are added at levels up to 200 parts per million to increase antimicrobial effectiveness. Although allergy to alcohol-only rubs is rare, fragrances, preservatives and quats can cause contact allergies.<ref>{{ cite journal | author= de Groot AC | title = Contact allergy to cosmetics: causative ingredients | journal = Contact Dermatitis | volume = 17 | year = 1987 | pmid=3652687 | issue=1 | pages=26–34 | doi=10.1111/j.1600-0536.1987.tb02640.x}}</ref> These other ingredients do not evaporate like alcohol and accumulate leaving a "sticky" residue until they are removed with soap and water.
The most common brands of alcohol hand rubs include Aniosgel, Avant, Sterillium, Desderman and Allsept S. All hospital hand rubs must conform to certain regulations like EN 12054 for hygienic treatment and surgical disinfection by hand-rubbing. Products with a claim of "99.99% reduction" or 4Log reduction are ineffective in hospital environment, since the reduction must be more than "99.99%".<ref name="cvvs"/>
The hand sanitizer dosing systems for hospitals are designed to deliver a measured amount of the product for staff. They are dosing pumps screwed onto a bottle or are specially designed dispensers with refill bottles. Dispensers for surgical hand disinfection are usually equipped with elbow controlled mechanism or infrared sensors to avoid any contact with the pump.
=== Surgical hand disinfection ===
Hands must be disinfected before any surgical procedure by hand washing with mild soap and then hand-rubbing with a sanitizer. Surgical disinfection requires a larger dose of the hand-rub and a longer rubbing time than is ordinarily used. It is usually done in two applications according to specific hand-rubbing techniques, EN1499 (hygienic handwash), and EN 1500 (hygienic hand disinfection) to ensure that antiseptic is applied everywhere on the surface of the hand.<ref>{{ cite journal | doi= 10.1053/jhin.2002.1357 |vauthors=Kampf G, Ostermeyer C | title = Inter-laboratory reproducibility of the hand disinfection reference procedure of EN 1500 | journal = J Hosp Infect| volume = 53 | issue=4 |pages=304–6 | date = Apr 2003 | pmid= 12660128 }}</ref>
=== Alcohol-free === [[File:Alcohol Free Hand Sanitizer.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Alcohol-free hand sanitizer]]
Some hand sanitizer products use agents other than alcohol to kill microorganisms, such as [[povidone-iodine]], [[benzalkonium chloride]] or [[triclosan]].<ref name="Boyce John M., Pittet Didier"/>
The World Health Organization (WHO) and the CDC recommends "persistent" antiseptics for hand sanitizers. Persistent activity is defined as the prolonged or extended antimicrobial activity that prevents or inhibits the proliferation or survival of microorganisms after application of the product. This activity may be demonstrated by sampling a site several minutes or hours after application and demonstrating bacterial antimicrobial effectiveness when compared with a baseline level. This property also has been referred to as "residual activity." Both substantive and nonsubstantive active ingredients can show a persistent effect if they substantially lower the number of bacteria during the wash period.
Laboratory studies have shown lingering benzalkonium chloride may be associated with antibiotic resistance in [[Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus|MRSA]]<ref>{{cite journal | title = Increase in Resistance of Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus to β-Lactams Caused by Mutations Conferring Resistance to Benzalkonium Chloride, a Disinfectant Widely Used in Hospitals| pmc= 89614 | year = 1999 | last1 = Akimitsu | first1 = N | last2 = Hamamoto | first2 = H | last3 = Inoue | first3 = RI | last4 = Shoji | first4 = M | last5 = Akamine | first5 = A | last6 = Takemori | first6 = KI | last7 = Hamasaki | first7 = N | last8 = Sekimizu | first8 = K | volume = 43 | issue = 12 | pages = 3042–3043 | journal = Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy | pmid = 10651623}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol7no3_supp/levy.htm| title = Antibacterial Household Products: Cause for Concern| accessdate = 2001-06-01| publisher = Centers for Disease Control and Prevention| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20010816054514/http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol7no3_supp/levy.htm| archivedate = 2001-08-16| df = }}</ref> while no mechanism for resistance to alcohol has ever been described in bacteria.<ref>{{cite journal| url = http://www.infectioncontroltoday.com/articles/400/400_2c1feat6.html| title = CDC's Endorsement of Alcohol Hand Rubs Launches New Era in Hand Hygiene| date = December 1, 2002| first = Kathy| last = Dix| journal = Infection Control Today| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090123033742/http://www.infectioncontroltoday.com/articles/400/400_2c1feat6.html| archivedate = January 23, 2009| df = }}</ref> Where alcohol sanitizers utilize 62%, or higher, alcohol by weight, only .1 to .13% of benzalkonium chloride by weight provides equivalent antimicrobial effectiveness.
Triclosan has been shown to accumulate in [[biosolids]] in the environment, one of the top seven organic contaminants in waste water according to the [[National Toxicology Program]]<ref>{{cite web| url = http://ntp.niehs.nih.gov/files/Triclosan_Concept_final-100608_508.pdf| title = Hand NTP Research Concept: Triclosan| accessdate = 2008-11-20| publisher = National Toxicology Project| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090510165612/http://ntp.niehs.nih.gov/files/Triclosan_Concept_final-100608_508.pdf| archivedate = 2009-05-10| df = }}</ref> Triclosan leads to various problems with natural biological systems,<ref name="pmid9707111">{{cite journal |vauthors=McMurry LM, Oethinger M, Levy SB |title=Triclosan targets lipid synthesis |journal=Nature |volume=394 |issue=6693 |pages=531–2 |year=1998 |pmid=9707111 |doi=10.1038/28970|bibcode=1998Natur.394..531M }}</ref> and triclosan, when combined with chlorine e.g. from tap water, produces [[Dioxins and dioxin-like compounds|dioxins]], a probable [[carcinogen]] in humans.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.scbwmi.org/PDFs/WMI_Triclosan_FinalJan06.pdf| title = Environmental Emergence of Triclosan| format = PDF| accessdate = 2006-01-01| publisher = Santa Clara Basin Watershed Management Initiative| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080603072608/http://www.scbwmi.org/PDFs/WMI_Triclosan_FinalJan06.pdf| archivedate = 2008-06-03| df = }}</ref> However, 90–98% of triclosan in waste water biodegrades by both photolytic or natural biological processes or is removed due to [[sorption]] in waste water treatment plants. Numerous studies show that only very small traces are detectable in the effluent water that reaches rivers.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heidler |first1=Jochen |last2=Halden |first2=Rolf U. |date=March 2007 |title=Mass balance assessment of triclosan removal during conventional sewage treatment |journal=Chemosphere |volume=66 |issue=2 |pages=362–9 |url=http://cibasc.com/index/ind-index/ind-per_car/ind-pc-ah/ind-pc-triclosan/ind-pc-triclosan-prod-safety-environmental-questions-2.htm |accessdate=2010-01-25 |pmid=16766013 |doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2006.04.066|bibcode=2007Chmsp..66..362H }}</ref>
A series of studies show that photodegradation of triclosan produced [[2,4-dichlorophenol]] and 2,8-dichlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (2,8-DCDD). The 2,4-dichlorophenol itself is known to be biodegradable as well as photodegradable.<ref>European Commission 2000</ref>{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}} For DCDD, one of the non-toxic compounds of the dioxin family,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0045-6535(90)90067-4 |title=Comparison of the toxicity of several polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzofuran in embryos of the Japanese medaka (Oryzias latipes) |year=1990 |last1=Wisk |first1=Joseph D. |last2=Cooper |first2=Keith R. |journal=Chemosphere |volume=20 |issue=3–4 |pages=361–377|bibcode=1990Chmsp..20..361W }}</ref> a conversion rate of 1% has been reported and estimated half-lives suggest that it is photolabile as well.<ref>Aranami et al. 2007</ref>{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}} The formation-decay kinetics of DCDD are also reported by Sanchez-Prado et al. (2006) who claim "transformation of triclosan to toxic dioxins has never been shown and is highly unlikely."<ref>{{cite journal|last2=Llompart|first2=Maria|last3=Lores|first3=Marta|last4=García-Jares|first4=Carmen|last5=Bayona|first5=Josep M.|last6=Cela|first6=Rafael|date=2006|title=Monitoring the photochemical degradation of triclosan in wastewater by UV light and sunlight using solid-phase microextraction|journal=Chemosphere|volume=65|issue=8|pages=1338–47|doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2006.04.025|pmid=16735047|last1=Sanchez-Prado|first1=Lucia|bibcode=2006Chmsp..65.1338S}}<!--| accessdate =2010-01-25--></ref>
Alcohol-free hand sanitizers may be effective immediately while on the skin, but the solutions themselves can become contaminated because alcohol is an in-solution preservative and without it, the alcohol-free solution itself is susceptible to contamination. However, even alcohol-containing hand sanitizers can become contaminated if the alcohol content is not properly controlled or the sanitizer is grossly contaminated with microorganisms during manufacture. In June 2009, alcohol-free Clarcon Antimicrobial Hand Sanitizer was pulled from the US market by the FDA, which found the product contained gross contamination of extremely high levels of various bacteria, including those which can "cause opportunistic infections of the skin and underlying tissues and could result in medical or surgical attention as well as permanent damage". Gross contamination of any hand sanitizer by bacteria during manufacture will result in the failure of the effectiveness of that sanitizer and possible infection of the treatment site with the contaminating organisms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/ForConsumers/ConsumerUpdates/ucm164845.htm |accessdate=2009-06-15 |title=Consumers Warned Not to Use Clarcon Skin Products |date=June 15, 2009 |publisher=U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614130646/http://www.fda.gov/ForConsumers/ConsumerUpdates/ucm164845.htm |archivedate=June 14, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
==Society and culture== Some products claim to kill microorganisms naturally, although these claims are not substantiated in any FDA monograph. All hand sanitizer products require [[National Drug Code]] designation in the United States and [[natural product number]] designation in Canada. {{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
==See also== * [[List of cleaning products]]
== Notes == {{reflist| group="note"}}
== Sources == <!--<nowiki> See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref> and </ref> tags, and the template below. </nowiki>-->
{{reflist|32em}}
==External links== *{{cite web|accessdate= |url=https://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/firesafety/aha_meeting.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308220645/http://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/firesafety/aha_meeting.htm |archivedate=2008-03-08 |title=Executive Summary: National Stakeholders Meeting on Alcohol-Based Hand-Rubs and Fire Safety in Health Care Facilities |date= July 22, 2003 |publisher=[[American Hospital Association]], Co-Hosted by the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control & Prevention]] (CDC) and AHA}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Explosives]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
Addition of historical information about hot air engines.
revision.text:
{{thermodynamics|cTopic=Processes and Cycles}} [[File:Stirlingov motor princip.png|thumb|right|250px|Illustration of a low temperature differential (LTD) hot air engine. 1. Power piston, 2. Cold end of cylinder, 3.Displacer piston 4. Hot end of cylinder Q1. Heat in, Q2. Heat out.]] A '''hot air engine'''<ref name="hae-hae02">{{cite web|url=http://hotairengines.org/|title=An Inquiry into the Hot Air Engines of the 19th Century|work=hotairengines.org}}</ref> (historically called an '''air engine''' or '''[[caloric theory|caloric]] engine'''<ref>{{cite book|author=Robert Sier|title=Hot air caloric and stirling engines. Vol.1, A history|edition=1st Edition (Revised)|publisher=L.A. Mair|year=1999|isbn=0-9526417-0-4}}</ref>) is any [[heat engine]] that uses the expansion and contraction of [[air]] under the influence of a temperature change to convert [[thermal energy]] into [[mechanical work]]. These engines may be based on a number of [[#Thermodynamic cycles|thermodynamic cycles]] encompassing both open cycle devices such as those of [[George Cayley|Sir George Cayley]]<ref name="caley">{{cite web|url=http://hotairengines.org/stirling-engines-inventors/cayley|title=Cayley's life and Air Engines|work=hotairengines.org}}</ref> and [[John Ericsson]]<ref name="haeericsson">{{cite web|url=http://hotairengines.org/stirling-engines-inventors/ericsson|title=Ericsson's life and Air Engines|work=hotairengines.org}}</ref> and the closed cycle engine of [[Robert Stirling]]<ref name="haestirling">{{cite web|url=http://hotairengines.org/stirling-engines-inventors/stirling|title=Stirling's life and Air Engines|work=hotairengines.org}}</ref>. Hot air engines are distinct from the better known internal combustion based engine and steam engine.
In a typical implementation, air is repeatedly heated and cooled in a [[Cylinder (engine)|cylinder]] and the resulting expansion and contraction is used to move a [[piston]] and produce useful [[mechanical work]].
==Definition==
[[File:Thinktank Birmingham - object 1961S01481.00001(1).jpg|thumb|A [[praxinoscope]] made by Ernst Plank, of [[Nuremberg]], Germany, and powered by a miniature hot air engine. It is now in the collection of [[Thinktank, Birmingham Science Museum]].]]
The term "hot air engine" specifically excludes any engine performing a [[thermodynamic cycle]] in which the working fluid undergoes a [[phase transition]], such as the [[Rankine cycle]]. Also excluded are conventional [[internal combustion engine]]s, in which heat is added to the working fluid by combustion of fuel within the working cylinder. Continuous combustion types, such as [[George Brayton]]'s Ready Motor and the related [[gas turbine]], could be seen as borderline cases.
==History== The expansive property of heated air was known to the ancients. [[Hero of Alexandria]]'s ''Pneumatica'' describes devices that might be used to automatically open temple doors when a fire was lit on a sacrificial altar. Devices called hot air engines, or simply ''air engines'', have been recorded from as early as 1699. In 1699, [[Guillaume Amontons]] (1663–1705) presented, to the Royal Academy of Sciences in Paris, a report on his invention: a wheel that was made to turn by heat<ref name="haeamontons-hae04">{{cite web|url=http://hotairengines.org/stirling-engines-inventors/amontons/amontons-heated-air-engine/|title=Amontons' Fire Wheel|work=hotairengines.org}}</ref>. The wheel was mounted vertically. Around the wheel's hub were water-filled chambers. Air-filled chambers on the wheel's rim were heated by a fire under one side of the wheel. The heated air expanded and, via tubes, forced water from one chamber to another, unbalancing the wheel and causing it to turn.
See: * Amontons (20 June 1699) [https://books.google.com/books?id=_czOAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA114#v=onepage&q&f=false "Moyen de substituer commodement l'action du feu, à la force des hommes et des chevaux pour mouvoir les machines"] (Means of conveniently substituting the action of fire for the force of men and horses in order to move [i.e., power] machines), ''Mémoires de l'Académie Royale des Sciences'', pages 112-126. The ''Mémoires'' appear in the ''Histoire de l'Académie Royale des Sciences, année 1699'', which was published in 1732. The operation of Amontons' ''moulin à feu'' (fire mill) is explained on pages 123-126; his machine is illustrated on the plate following page 126. * For an account of Amontons' fire-powered wheel in English, see: Robert Stuart, ''Historical and Descriptive Anecdotes of Steam-engines and of Their Inventors and Improvers'' (London, England: Wightman and Cramp, 1829), vol. 1, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YU01AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA130#v=onepage&q&f=false pages 130-132] ; an illustration of the machine appears on [https://books.google.com/books?id=YU01AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA351#v=onepage&q&f=false page 351].</ref> around the time when the [[Gas laws|laws of gasses]] were first set out, and early patents include those of [[Henry Wood (engineer)|Henry Wood]], Vicar of High Ercall near [[Coalbrookdale]] Shropshire (English patent 739 of 1759) and [[Thomas Mead (engineer)|Thomas Mead]], an engineer from Sculcoats Yorkshire (English patent 979 of 1791),<ref>{{cite book|author=Robert Sier|title=Hot air caloric and stirling engines. Vol.1, A history, page 56|edition=1st Edition (Revised)|publisher=L.A. Mair|year=1999|isbn=0-9526417-0-4}}</ref> the latter in particular containing the essential elements of a [[displacer]] type engine (Mead termed it the transferrer). It is unlikely that either of these patents resulted in an actual engine and the earliest workable example was probably the open cycle [[furnace]] gas engine of the English inventor [[George Cayley|Sir George Cayley]] {{circa|1807}}<ref>[http://engine.stirling.cz/tedom-stirling-engine-history.html Stirling engine history]</ref><ref>[http://www.lamair.co.uk/book2.htm Detailed contents of the book ''Hot air caloric and stirling engines. Vol.1, A history'']</ref>
It is likely that [[Robert Stirling]]'s air engine of 1818, which incorporated his innovative ''Economiser'' (patented in 1816) was the first air engine put to practical work.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Finkelstein, T |author2=Organ, A.J|title=Chapter 2.2 Air Engines|publisher=Professional Engineering Publishing|year=2001|isbn=1-86058-338-5}}</ref> The economiser, now known as the [[Stirling engine#Regenerator|regenerator]], stored heat from the hot portion of the engine as the air passed to the cold side, and released heat to the cooled air as it returned to the hot side. This innovation improved the efficiency of Stirling's engine and should be present in any air engine that is properly called a [[Stirling engine]].
Stirling patented a second hot air engine, together with his brother James, in 1827. They inverted the design so that the hot ends of the displacers were underneath the machinery and they added a compressed air pump so the air within could be increased in pressure to around 20 atmospheres. It is stated by Chambers to have been unsuccessful, owing to mechanical defects and to “the unforeseen accumulation of heat, not fully extracted by the sieves or sin ill passages in the cool part of the regenerator, of which the external surface was not sufficiently large to throw off the unrecovered heat when the engine was working with highly compressed air.”
Parkinson and Crossley, English patent, 1828 came up with their own hot air engine. In this engine the air-chamber is partly exposed, by submergence in cold water, to external cold, and its upper portion is heated by steam. An internal vessel moves up and down in this chamber, and in so doing displaces the air, alternately exposing it to the hot and cold influences of the cold water and the hot steam, changing its temperature and expansive condition. The fluctuations cause the reciprocation of a piston in a cylinder to whose ends the air-chamber is alternately connected.
In 1829 Arnott patented his air expansion machine where a fire is placed on a grate near the bottom of a close cylinder, and the cylinder is full of fresh air recently admitted. A loose piston is pulled upwards so that all the air in the cylinder above will be made to pass by a tube through the fire, and will receive an increased elasticity tending to the expansion or increase of volume, which the fire is capable of giving it.
He is followed the next year (1830) by Captain Ericsson who patented his second hot air engine. The specification describes it more particularly, as consisting of a “circular chamber, in which a cone is made to revolve on a shaft or axis by means of leaves or wings, alternately exposed to the pressure of steam; these wings or leaves being made to work through slits or openings of a circular plane, which revolves obliquely to, and is thereby kept in contact with the side of the cone.”
Ericsson built his third hot air engine (the caloric engine) in 1833 which excited so much interest a few years ago in England; and which, if it should be brought into practical operation, will prove the most important mechanical invention ever conceived by the human mind, and one that will confer greater benefits on civilized life than any that has ever preceded it. For the object of it is the production of mechanical power by the agency of heat, at an expenditure of fuel so exceedingly small, that man will have an almost unlimited mechanical force at his command, in regions where fuel may now be said hardly to exist.
1838 sees the patent of Franchot hot air engine, certainly the hot air engine that was best following the Carnot requirements.
So far all these air engines have been unsuccessful, but the technology was maturing. In 1842, James Stirling, the brother of Robert, build the famous Dundee Stirling Engine. This one at least lasted 2-3 years but then was discontinued due to improper technical contrivances. Hot air engines is a story of trials and errors, and it took another 20 years before hot air engines could be used on an industrial scale. The first reliable hot air engines were built by Shaw, Roper, Ericsson. Several thousands of them were built.
==Thermodynamic cycles== {{Main article|Thermodynamic cycle}} A hot air engine [[thermodynamic cycle]] can (ideally) be made out of 3 or more [[Thermodynamic process|process]]es (typical 4). The processes can be any of these: * [[isothermal process]] (at constant temperature, maintained with heat added or removed from a heat source or sink) * [[isobaric process]] (at constant pressure) *[[isochoric process|isometric / isochoric process]] (at constant volume) *[[adiabatic process]] (no heat is added or removed from the working fluid) ** [[isentropic process]], [[reversible adiabatic process]] (no heat is added or removed from the working fluid - and the [[entropy]] is constant) *[[isenthalpic process]] (the [[enthalpy]] is constant)
Some examples (not all hot air cycles, as defined above) are as follows: {{Table of thermodynamic cycles}}
Yet another example is the [[Vuilleumier cycle]]. <ref>{{cite book|author=Wurm, Jaroslav|title=Stirling and Vuilleumier heat pumps: design and applications|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=1991|isbn=0-07-053567-1}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Stirling engine]] *[[Thermoacoustic hot air engine]] *[[Manson-Guise Engine]] *[[Flame-licker engine]] *[[Carnot heat engine]] *[[Timeline of heat engine technology]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Hot air engines}} {{EB1911 poster|Air-Engine}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070926022555/http://www.mech.canterbury.ac.nz/documents/sc_intro.pdf Introduction to Stirling-Cycle Machines] *[http://www.stirlingengines.org.uk/pioneers/pioneers.html Pioneers in Air Engine Designs] (Select the desired biography) *[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/1321343.pdf Apparatus for the Method of Heat Differentiation] Vuilleumier patent *[http://hotairengines.org Inquiry into the Hot Air Engines of the 19th Century]
{{Thermodynamic cycles|state=uncollapsed}} {{Heat engines}}
{{Authority control}}
