{|{{Infobox ship begin |display title=ital}} {{Infobox ship image | Ship image = [[File:Scarabeo9 Thailand.jpg|frameless]] | Ship caption = Scarabeo 9 outside Phuket, Thailand, undergoing [[sea trials]] }} {{Infobox ship career | Ship name = '''''Scarabeo 9''''' | Ship owner = [[Saipem]] | Ship operator = Saipem | Ship registry = [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], {{BAH}} | Ship route = | Ship ordered = | Ship builder =*[[Yantai Raffles Shipyard]] *[[Keppel FELS]] | Ship original cost = US$750 million | Ship yard number = YRF-2006-189 | Ship way number = | Ship laid down = 1 April 2008 | Ship launched = | Ship completed = 19 August 2011 | Ship acquired = | Ship maiden voyage = | Ship in service = 2011 | Ship out of service = | Ship identification =*[[Call sign]]: C6YV7 *[[Det Norske Veritas|DNV ID:]] 27764 *{{IMO Number|9480423}} *[[Maritime Mobile Service Identity|MMSI no.:]] 311046800 | Ship status = Operational | Ship notes = <ref name=dnv/> }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Ship type = [[Det Norske Veritas|DNV]] 676–Column-stabilised Unit | Ship tonnage = {{DWT|23,965}}; {{GRT|36,863}}; {{NetT|11,059}} | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|115|m|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|78|m|abbr=on}} | Ship height = | Ship draught = {{convert|23.6|m|abbr=on}} | Ship depth = {{convert|35.4|m|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship power = | Ship propulsion = 8 x Wärtsilä 12V32LNE 7,200 BHP | Ship speed = | Ship capacity = | Ship crew = 200 | Ship notes = <ref name="dnv">{{cite ship register |register=DNV |id=27764 |shipname=Scarabeo 9 |accessdate=2012-07-01 }}</ref> }} |} '''''Scarabeo 9''''' is a Frigstad D90-type ultra deepwater 6th generation [[semi-submersible]] [[drilling rig]]. It is owned and operated by [[Saipem]]. It was named by Anna Tatka, the wife of Pietro Franco Tali, [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of Saipem.<ref name=marinelink310711> {{cite news | title= Keppel Completes Saipem Ultra Deepwater Rig | url= http://www.marinelink.com/news/completes-deepwater339733.aspx | work = MarineLink | date = 2011-07-31 | accessdate= 2012-07-07}} </ref> The vessel is registered in [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], [[Bahamas]].<ref name=dnv/>
==Description== ''Scarabeo 9'' is one of the largest offshore drilling rigs in the world.<ref name=offshoreenergytoday200112/><ref name=mi071111> {{cite news | title= Scarabeo 9 – The Massive Oil Drilling Vessel | url= http://www.marineinsight.com/marine/marine-news/featured/scarabeo-9-%E2%80%93-the-massive-oil-drilling-vessel/ | work = Marine Insight News Network | date = 2011-11-07 | accessdate= 2012-07-08}} </ref> It is the first (and as of 2012 the only) Frigstad Engineering developed Frigstad D90 design rig ever built.<ref name=upstream200810> {{cite news | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = [[NHST Media Group]] | title = Saipem may move from CIMC Raffles | author = Xu Yihe | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/hardcopy/news/article226857.ece | date = 2011-01-10 | accessdate=2012-07-09}} </ref> The rig is able to operate at the water depth up to {{convert|11811|ft}}, which is classified by the oil industry as "ultra-deepwater", and its drilling depth is {{convert|15200|m}}.<ref name=saipem>{{cite web | title=''Scarabeo 9'' | url= http://www.saipem.com/site/article.jsp?idArticle=5430&instance=2&node=2012&channel=2&ext=template/37DueColonne&int=article/1DefaultArticolo | date=2010-01-22 | publisher=[[Saipem]] | accessdate= 2012-07-01}}</ref><ref name=reuters260811/><ref name=reuters020212> {{cite news | title= Spain's Repsol begins Cuba offshore drilling-sources | url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/02/us-cuba-oil-idUSTRE8111X320120202 | agency = Reuters | first = Jeff | last = Franks | date = 2012-02-02 | accessdate= 2012-07-08}} </ref> The water depth still suitable for its operations is twice as much as for ''[[Deepwater Horizon]]''.<ref name=cda> {{cite report | title= As Cuba plans to drill in the Gulf of Mexico, U.S. policy poses needless risks to our national interest | url= http://democracyinamericas.org/pdfs/Cuba_Drilling_and_US_Policy.pdf | publisher = Center for Democracy in the Americas | year = 2011 | pages = 18; 26 | format = PDF | accessdate= 2012-07-08}} </ref> The drilling equipment was provided by the [[Norway|Norwegian]] engineering company [[Aker Solutions]].<ref name=upstream011010> {{cite news | newspaper = Upstream Online | publisher = NHST Media Group | title = Change of yard for the Scarabeo 9 rig | author = Tan Hwee Hwee; Xu Yihe | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/hardcopy/news/article1200272.ece | date = 2010-10-01 | accessdate=2012-07-09 | id = {{subscription required}}}} </ref>
''Scarabeo 9'' has a length of {{convert|115|m}} and a breadth of {{convert|78|m}}. Its gross tonnage is 36,863, dead weight tonnage 23,965, and net tonnage 11,059 tonnes.<ref name=dnv/> The vessel is powered by eight [[Wärtsilä]] 12V32 diesel engines.<ref name=dnv/> It is equipped with two cranes.<ref name=saipem/>
The rig includes quarters for up to 200 workers. There is also a helicopter deck suitable for MI8, S61, and EH101 helicopters.<ref name=saipem/> The rig has been described by the industry sources as "the latest technology for deepwater drilling operations."<ref name=cda/>
==Construction and delivery== [[File:TAISUN with SCARABEO 9.JPG|thumb|left|[[Taisun]] crane at the [[Yantai Raffles Shipyard]] holds the 17,100 metric ton deck box of ''Scarabeo 9'' in the air as the barge is moved out from underneath.]] ''Scarabeo 9'' was ordered by Frigstad Offshore, a [[Singapore]] based offshore drilling rigs management service company. For this purpose, a special project company Frigstad Discoverer was established in 2006. The original name of the vessel was decided to be ''Frigstad Oslo''. In 2007, the project company was acquired by Italian engineering and offshore services provider company Saipem and it was decided to rename the rig ''Scarabeo 9''.<ref name=frigstad/>
The rig cost US$750 million to build.<ref name=bbc151111> {{cite news | title= Cuban oil project fuels US anxieties | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-15737573 | work =[[BBC News]] | first = Michale | last = Voss | date = 2011-11-15 | accessdate= 2012-07-01}} </ref> It was constructed at the [[Yantai Raffles Shipyard]] in [[Yantai]], [[China]]. The contract was signed on 5 April 2006, the [[keel]] was laid on 1 April 2008, and originally the construction was to be completed in September 2009.<ref name=dnv/><ref name=upstream100111/> After several delays at the Yantai Raffles shipyard it was shipped to the [[Keppel FELS]] shipyard in Singapore for the final completion in 2010.<ref name=reuters260811> {{cite news | title= Chinese-built oil rig setting sail for Cuban waters | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/08/26/cuba-oil-idUKN1E77P03U20110826 | agency = [[Reuters]] | first = Jeff | last = Franks | date = 2011-08-26 | accessdate= 2012-07-07}} </ref> The reason of delays was related to a number of orders which were carried out simultaneously at the Yantai Raffles shipyard.<ref name=upstream200810/> Changing shipyards caused additional cost of between US$70 and 100 million.<ref name=upstream070111> {{cite news | newspaper = Upstream Online | publisher = NHST Media Group | title = Frigstad chases second tender for D-90 unit | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/hardcopy/news/article240911.ece | date = 2011-01-07 | accessdate=2012-07-08}} </ref> Beside of the Keppel FELS shipyard also the [[SembCorp Marine]]'s Jurong Shipyard in Singapore was considered for the completion works.<ref name=upstream011010/>
On its way to Singapore, a water leak occurred due to "water raining into the tanks from the top that was not been drained out."<ref name=upstream100111> {{cite news | newspaper = Upstream Online | publisher = NHST Media Group | title = Fresh delay for Scarabeo-9 | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article241069.ece | date = 2011-01-10 | accessdate=2012-07-08}} </ref> The incident caused an extensive inspection to assure its seaworthiness.<ref name=reuters260811/> The main part of Keppel's work involved the completion and commissioning of marine and drilling systems on board.<ref name=marinelink310711/>
The rig was delivered to Saipem on 25 August 2011.<ref name=frigstad> {{cite press release | title= Delivery of the "Scarabeo 9" Ultra Deepwater Drilling Unit | url= http://offshore.frigstad.com/newsDetails.aspx?newsID=119&type=pr&itemID=4 | publisher = Frigstad Offshore | date = 2011-08-25 | accessdate= 2012-07-07}} </ref> On her maiden voyage to Cuba, ''Scarabeo 9'' was escorted around the [[Cape of Good Hope]] by the [[Fairmount Marine]] owned [[tugboat]] ''Fairmount Glacier''.<ref name=fairmount> {{cite press release | title= Fairmount Glacier successfully assisted rig Scarabeo 9 | url= http://www.fairmount.nl/index.php/news/detail/229 | publisher = [[Fairmount Marine]] | date = 2011-11-18 | accessdate= 2012-07-07}} </ref>
==Compliance with the embargo against Cuba== The rig was specifically built for drilling in the waters of [[Cuba]]. It is compliant with the [[United States embargo against Cuba]], which limits the amount of American technology that can be used in equipment used there, as less than 10% of its parts are American-made.<ref name=reuters180511> {{cite news | title= Cuban oil rig set to cause waves in Washington | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/05/18/us-cuba-usa-rig-idUKTRE74H0L220110518 | agency = Reuters | first = Daniel | last = Wallis | date = 2011-05-18 | accessdate= 2012-07-07}} </ref><ref name=ct060612> {{cite news | title= PdVSA to perform exploratory drill | url= http://www.cubastandard.com/2012/06/06/pdvsa-to-perform-exploratory-drill/ | newspaper= Cuba Standard | date = 2012-06-06 | accessdate= 2012-07-02}} </ref><ref name=ap210112> {{cite news | title= With rig, offshore oil within Cuba's grasp | url= http://www.sltrib.com/csp/cms/sites/sltrib/pages/printerfriendly.csp?id=53335885 | newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]] | agency = [[Associated Press]] | first = Peter| last = Orsi | date = 2012-01-21 | accessdate= 2012-07-02}} </ref> The news agency [[Reuters]] has reported that only the [[blowout preventer]] of ''Scarabeo 9'' is manufactured in the United States.<ref name=offshoreenergytoday200112> {{cite news | title= Scarabeo 9 Arrives in Cuban Waters | url= http://www.offshoreenergytoday.com/scarabeo-9-arrives-in-cuban-waters/ | work = Offshore Energy Today | date = 2012-01-20 | accessdate= 2012-07-08}} </ref><ref name=reuters180511/> This is one of the most critical devices for [[Oil well|well]] control during the offshore drilling as malfunctioning of the blowout preventer was one of the reasons of the [[Deepwater Horizon explosion]].<ref name=offshoreenergytoday200112/> However, due to the United States embargo, the original equipment manufacturer is not allowed to provide spare parts or repair items for the blowout preventer.<ref name=ap210112/><ref name=gcaptain> {{cite news | title= Drilling Off Cuba, and How the Embargo Could be Very Costly for the US <!-- | url= http://gcaptain.com/drilling-cuba-embargo-badly/ --> | url = https://regator.com/p/256093073/drilling_off_cuba_and_how_the_embargo_could/ | work = gCaptain | first = Rob | last = Almeida | date = 2012-05-18 | accessdate= 2012-07-08}} </ref>
On its way to Cuba, in [[Trinidad]] it was inspected by the [[United States Coast Guard]] and [[Interior Department]] ([[Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement]]).<ref name=time270112> {{cite news | title= The Oil Off Cuba: Washington and Havana Dance at Arms Length Over Spill Prevention | url= http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2105598,00.html?xid=gonewsedit | newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]] | first = Tim | last = Padgett | date = 2012-01-27 | accessdate= 2012-07-02}} </ref> According to the statement by the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement, the vessel is generally compliant with existing international and U.S. standards.<ref name=offshoreenergytoday200112/><ref name=ct190112> {{cite news | title= Rig has arrived; offshore oil drilling begins | url= http://www.cubastandard.com/2012/01/19/it-has-arrived/ | newspaper= Cuba Standard | date = 2012-01-19 | accessdate= 2012-07-02}} </ref>
==Operation== ''Scarabeo 9'' drilled its first well on the Jagüey prospect in the North Cuba Basin for [[Repsol]] in the beginning of 2012.<ref name=bbc151111/><ref name=upstream100212> {{cite news | newspaper = Upstream Online | publisher = NHST Media Group | title = Repsol in oil chase off Cuba | first = Tom Darin | last = Liskey | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/hardcopy/news/article1231546.ece | date = 2012-02-10 | accessdate=2012-07-09 | id = {{subscription required}}}} </ref> Provider of immediate well intervention and other well-related subsea services was Helix Energy Solutions Group.<ref name=gcaptain/> After drilling for Repsol, ''Scarabeo 9'' was contracted to drill for [[Petronas]] and [[Gazprom Neft]] on the Catoche field off the north coast of [[Pinar del Río Province]], and for [[Petróleos de Venezuela]] on the Cabo de San Antonio prospect off the west coast of Cuba.<ref name=ct060612/><ref name=bloomberg151111> {{cite news | title= Cuba Shifts Oil Exploration After Repsol's Unsuccessful Search | url= http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-06-06/cuba-shifts-oil-exploration-after-repsol-s-unsuccessful-search | work =[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] | first = Eric | last = Sabo | date = 2012-06-06 | accessdate= 2012-07-02}} </ref><ref name=upstream050712> {{cite news | newspaper = Upstream Online | publisher = NHST Media Group | title = PDVSA to turn bit off Cuba | first = Tom Darin | last = Liskey | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/hardcopy/news/article1257638.ece | date = 2012-07-05 | accessdate=2012-07-09 | id = {{subscription required}}}} </ref> Repsol has also contracted the rig for drilling in [[Brazil]].<ref name=ct060612/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:2011 ships]] [[Category:Drilling rigs]] [[Category:Semi-submersibles]] [[Category:Ships built in China]] [[Category:Ships built in Singapore]] [[Category:Ships of the Bahamas]] [[Category:Eni]]

/* top */ hyphenated compound modifier "extra-thick"; hyphens are important--"extra thick" sans hyphen implies that there are two peels, one of them being thicker than the other
revision.text:
{{Infobox prepared food | name = Succade | image = Succade.jpg | caption = Diced succade | alternate_name = | country = | region = | creator = | course = | type = [[Confectionery]] | served = | main_ingredient = Candied [[peel (fruit)|peel]] of citrus | variations = | calories = | other = }}
'''Succade''' is the candied [[peel (fruit)|peel]] of any of the [[citrus]] species, especially from the [[citron]] or ''Citrus medica'' which is distinct with its extra-thick peel; in addition, the taste of the inner rind of the citron is less bitter than those of the other citrus.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fhN0VK2608QC&pg=RA1-PA159&dq=succade&ei=xkafR8bNE4G4zASpu7SuDg&sig=g2c6B0imgrlemt6C9KLAc1xh_Og|title=World Spice Plants|work=google.com}}</ref> However, the term is also occasionally applied to the peel, root,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-sAOJoEWb0C&pg=PA278&dq=succade&ei=xkafR8bNE4G4zASpu7SuDg#PPA278,M1|title=The Fyrst Boke of the Introduction of Knowledge Made by Andrew Borde, of ...|work=google.com}}</ref> or even entire fruit or vegetable like [[parsley]], [[fennel]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sDwUYfZEm2oC&pg=PA278&dq=succade&ei=xkafR8bNE4G4zASpu7SuDg&sig=vORgeIWwevyScJJjtbrea4M5gJ0|title=The Fyrst Boke of the Introduction of Knowledge|work=google.com}}</ref> and [[cucurbita]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H_MCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA358&dq=succade&lr=&ei=zE-fR-KiN5HCzAS_qt3vCg|title=The Treasury of Botany|work=google.com}}</ref> which have a bitter taste and are boiled with [[sugar]] to get a special "sweet and sour" outcome.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=AxsOAAAAIAAJ&q=succade&dq=succade&lr=&ei=a0ufR7aQJ5XaygTN-aD5CQ&pgis=1 Publications] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=-KAMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA283&dq=succade&lr=&ei=a0ufR7aQJ5XaygTN-aD5CQ#PPA283,M1 The Encyclopædia Britannica] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=o_o3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA549&dq=succade&lr=&ei=a0ufR7aQJ5XaygTN-aD5CQ Pharmaceutical Journal By Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=CfDcl2m-6BMC&pg=PA104&dq=succade&lr=&ei=l02fR4_OFZGSzQTJufDrCw Select Extra-tropical Plants Readily Eligible for Industrial Culture Or ...] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=hUF4ZOsq0vcC&pg=PA145&dq=succade&lr=&ei=406fR7vjF4nIyASg3Z2CBw The Life and Letters of Gilbert White of Selborne By Rashleigh Holt-White] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=Sr383CDpNM8C&pg=PA37&dq=succade&ei=xkafR8bNE4G4zASpu7SuDg&sig=Hdmq3XI9ZV8LX-ciSKmajt-CFHc The Book of Marmalade: Its Antecedents, Its History, and Its Role in the ... By C. Anne Wilson]* [https://books.google.com/books?id=kU5EQlDwgdkC&pg=PA118&dq=succade&ei=xkafR8bNE4G4zASpu7SuDg&sig=YFOKiGPj8cWIns7zUnpxk4WnsqE The Queen of Subtleties By Suzannah Dunn].</ref>
Fruits which are commonly candied also include [[Date Palm|dates]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZcoEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA120&dq=succade&lr=&ei=c1afR_j9MpfayASByZF9|title=The dictionary of trade products, manufacturing, and technical terms|work=google.com}}</ref> [[Maraschino cherry|cherries]], [[pineapple]], [[ginger]],<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/candied-fruit-candied-flowers Answers.com — candied fruit; candied flowers]. Retrieved on 2008-01-06.</ref> and the rind of [[watermelon]].<ref>[http://isgropastries.com/news/news6.html Isgro Pasticceria] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121192319/http://www.isgropastries.com/news/news6.html |date=2008-11-21 }}</ref>
==Name== The word '''succade''' is most probably derived from the [[Latin]] ''succidus'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iZASAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA888&dq=succade&lr=&ei=a0ufR7aQJ5XaygTN-aD5CQ|title=Das lateinische Sprachmaterial im Wortschatze der deutschen, französischen ...|work=google.com}}</ref> but according to others the name may have originated from the Hebrew word [[sukkah]], the temporary booth that Jews build on the holiday of [[Sukkot]]. The [[citron]], known in [[Hebrew]] as an ''[[etrog]]'', is one of the symbolic [[Four Species]] used on that holiday. After Sukkot, some Jews candy the ''etrog'' or make [[marmalade]] from it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gernot-katzers-spice-pages.com/engl/Citr_lim.html?redirect=1|title=Spice Pages: Lemon (Citrus limon)|author=Gernot Katzer|work=gernot-katzers-spice-pages.com}}</ref>
[[File:Simanim.jpg|thumb|A pure citron, of any kind, has a large portion of [[Mesocarp#Mesocarp|albedo]], which is important for the production of ''Succade''.]] [[File:Orange cross section description.png|thumb|Location of mesocarp or albedo in a [[Citrus × sinensis|sweet orange]]]] While the word ''Succade'' was widely used in [[German language|German]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RF4SAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA505&dq=succade&ei=xkafR8bNE4G4zASpu7SuDg#PPA505,M1|title=A New English-German and German-English Dictionary: German and English|work=google.com}}</ref> today it is usually called ''Zitronat''. The [[France|French]] called it '' fruit glacé '' or '' fruit confit '', and is also known as ''candied fruit'' or ''crystallized fruit''. It has been around since the 14th century.
==Production== The ''citron'' fruits are halved, depulped, immersed in seawater or ordinary salt water to ferment for about 40 days, the [[brine]] being changed every two weeks; rinsed, and put in denser brine in wooden barrels for storage and for export. After partial de-salting and boiling to soften the peel, it is candied in a strong sugar solution. The candied peel is sun-dried or put up in jars for future use. Candying is traditionally done in [[Livorno]], [[Italy]], where they gathered the [[Corsican citron]]s from [[Corsica]], the [[Diamante citron]]s from [[Liguria]], [[Naples]], [[Calabria]] and [[Sicily]], and the [[Greek citron]] from [[Greece]] through [[Trieste]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=DQYXAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA736&lpg=PA736&dq=candied+citron+leghorn&source=bl&ots=XZNW39VpGu&sig=A95QGYASjKGJxeN4Uu8_ZGyIJIs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Z7XWU5CgH6XgsATzjYLwDA&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=candied%20citron%20leghorn&f=false Citron Leaves book] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=tsNBAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA336&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=O28KSbLRJIGmMtyKwZ4F#PPA337,M1 The Cultivated Oranges and Lemons] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=3Uo_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1116&lpg=PA1116&dq=candied+citron+leghorn&source=bl&ots=FHdZrczt2L&sig=JSHuQ6zgnMbWrHujE1xmrqkaPhw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Z7XWU5CgH6XgsATzjYLwDA&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=candied%20citron%20leghorn&f=false Daily Consular book] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=9GICAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA86&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F#PPA86,M1 The Pharmaceutical Journal-Consular report] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=SvcWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA771&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F The Gardeners Chronicle] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=vURJAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA404&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F Biennial Report] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=z89BAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA193&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F Report Google Books] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=26UTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT109&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F Parliamentary Papers] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=vskCAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA434&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F The Dublin REview] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=PiBLAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA182&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F Monthly Consular] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=4z-3AAAAIAAJ&pg=RA3-PA105&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=33AKSYyPD5HEMZGivJ4F Bulletin Victoria] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=74QCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA62&dq=citron+candying+leghorn&lr=&ei=AXMKSeeDKonIMuqnwZ4F Science] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=26UTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT108&dq=ordinary+citron&lr=&ei=tmYfSIaFOoiWzATanojWBg#PPT108,M1 Parliamentary Papers] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=c_81AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA337&dq=ordinary+citron&lr=&ei=5GgfSNLaJYiWzATanojWBg#PPA337,M1 Citrus Fruits] * [https://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/morton/citron.html The Purdue University] * [https://www.cretancitron.gr/ The Citron in Crete] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128063930/http://www.cretancitron.gr/ |date=2012-11-28 }} * [http://www.vinetreeorchards.com/citron.htm Vine Tree Orchards] </ref><ref name="Food Facts">{{cite web|url=https://www.foodreference.com/html/fcandiedfruit.html|title=Food, Facts, and Trivia — Candied Fruit|accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
The continual process of drenching the fruit in syrup causes the fruit to become saturated with [[sugar]], thereby preventing the growth of [[Food microbiology|spoilage microorganisms]].<ref name="Britannica">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/topic-92425/candied-fruit|title=Britannica Online Encyclopedia — Candied Fruit|accessdate=2007-11-23}}</ref>
In the [[Eastern Bloc]], [[ersatz good|ersatz]] succade and [[orangeat]] were prepared from unripe tomatoes and carrots respectively, as citrus fruits were scarce goods that could not be produced domestically.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-13490070.html |title=Geheimsache Süßtafel |date=22 April 1991 |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |language=de |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
==Uses== Succade is sometimes used in [[cakes]], as a filling for [[pound cake]], [[oliebol]], [[plum pudding]], [[Florentine biscuit|florentine]]s, [[sfogliatelle]], [[fruitcake]] or [[ontbijtkoek]]. It is also added to [[raisin bread]]. Succade is often combined with [[Ribes|currant]]s, [[raisin]]s, [[cherries]] and [[hazelnut]]s. Candied citron peel is often coated in [[chocolate]] and eaten as [[confectionery]]. Chopped succade is also used in [[cannoli]]. [[File:Halv sukat.JPG|thumb|A citron halved and depulped, cooked in sugar.]]
===Recipes=== Recipes vary from region to region, but the general principle is to boil the fruit, [[Steeping|steep]] it in increasingly strong sugar solutions for a number of weeks, and then dry off any remaining water.
The high sugar content of finished glacé fruits inhibits the growth of microorganisms, and glacé fruits will keep for a number of years without any additional methods of preservation.
Fruits that hold up well to being preserved in this manner include [[Cherry|cherries]], [[plum]]s, [[peach]]es, [[apricot]]s, [[pear]]s, [[Carambola|starfruit]], [[pineapple]], [[apple]]s, [[orange (fruit)|oranges]], [[lemon]]s, [[Lime (fruit)|lime]]s and [[clementine]]s. [[Angelica archangelica|Angelica]] is rarely seen in Western cooking except as a glacé fruit.
==See also== * [[Candied fruit]] * [[Chenpi]] * [[Fruit anatomy]] * [[Mincemeat#A 19th century recipe|Mincemeat]] * [[Orangeat]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120229165709/http://www.historicfood.com/Banniet%20tort%20recipe.htm Historic Food]
{{citrus}}
[[Category:Citrus]] [[Category:Confectionery]] [[Category:Food preservation]]
